Triggering Event: He arrived at the school parking lot to find his colleague's brand-new electric car parked next to his decade-old sedan, still humming softly as it cooled down.
Generated Assessment: He simply cannot believe that this is happening. This is either the best day ever or the absolute worst nightmare come true. How can one thing be both? The absurdity of it all makes him question everything he thought he knew about himself and the world around him.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

After closing up the store, he walked home alone in the cold drizzle. Passing families huddled under umbrellas, their laughter echoing, he felt a familiar ache. Reaching his empty apartment, he found a note from his ex-wife on the door, reminding him about the custody hearing tomorrow. He crumpled it up, throwing it into the darkness of the unlit room.

He remembered how one day, after getting drunk, he’d called her, saying, “If you ever decide to leave me, just tell me.” Her voice was laced with tears as she replied, “Never, I love you.” But then what if... she doesn’t feel the same way anymore? What if she's tired of me? What if she wants someone else? No! That can't be true! We've had so many good times together. We have two beautiful kids. I know she cares about them. And yet, what if... His mind continued to spiral, conjuring worst-case scenarios. What if our son falls ill? What if our daughter gets hurt? What if my car breaks down? What if I get fired? What if I lose my job and can't support them? What if... what if... It seemed like every possibility ended in heartbreak, failure, or abandonment. His thoughts swirled with anxiety, making his chest tight. He wondered if he was just waiting for an excuse to give up. In this scenario, he is likely to ask more questions like “what if

Triggering Event: She stood in the quiet kitchen, the familiar scent of herbs and spices usually comforting, now heavy with memory. Her calloused hands, once agile and confident, trembled slightly as she held a well-worn photograph - her late husband's favorite dish, his smile wide and genuine beneath the generous helping of her homemade macaroni and cheese. A pang of remorse shot through her; she hadn't made it since he passed two years ago. The recipe book lay untouched on the counter, its pages dog-eared and grease-stained, a silent reproach. She'd been too afraid to face his joy, his absence, all wrapped up in that one dish. Today, though, she felt an inexplicable urge, a whisper of him in her ear, urging her to cook it again.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't shake off the feeling of guilt as she opened the cookbook. The pages were yellowed, but the recipes remained unchanged. It was as if time had frozen, and she was stuck reliving memories. Every page told a story, every note a reminder of what she'd lost. The dishes weren't just food; they represented moments shared, laughter, and love. But with each turn of the page, the pain grew, and she began to see the book as a burden. It wasn't just the recipes that weighed heavily on her; it was the memories they held, the emotions tied to each dish, and the silence that followed. The more she flipped through the pages, the more she felt trapped by her grief, unable to escape the past. It seemed impossible to find solace when every page held a piece of her heart, refusing to let go. The book became a constant reminder of what she'd lost, and how difficult it would be to move forward. It was no longer just a collection of recipes; it had become a symbol of her sorrow, a tangible representation of her inability to heal.

It’s like our minds are connected somehow, and when they’re aligned, it creates this amazing sense of unity. And I’m pretty sure I saw him glance down for a split second before looking back up, which might have been a sign of agreement, but who knows? So, yeah, I bet he wasn’t really trying to be rude, he was probably just being kind and didn’t realize how it would affect me. That makes perfect sense, doesn’t it? Triggering Event: Mr. H., a software engineer in his late seventies, was browsing through old photographs when he stumbled upon one of his ex-wife laughing with her new husband at their wedding. He felt a surge of bitterness and vengefulness rise within him, clenching his fist around the photograph before carefully placing it face down on the table.
Generated Assessment: Mr. H. is an extremely bitter man who has been harboring resentment towards his ex-wife for over 30 years. This recent discovery serves as just another reminder of how much he feels wronged by her decision to marry someone else after leaving him. His anger and jealousy are so intense that they have become a constant companion, making it difficult for him to see things objectively. When faced with this painful reality, he tends to focus solely on the negative aspects, magnifying them while minimizing everything else.

Triggering Event: While grading papers late into the night, she noticed a careless comment scrawled across one: "You're so boring, Mrs.!" Her anger surged, not at the rudeness, but at the realization it was written by her own stepson.

Triggering Event: In her quiet apartment, she finds an old voicemail from her ex-husband, left on her work phone by mistake. She hears his voice, still raw with hurt after their divorce. He'd called to share news about their mutual friend's wedding, but she'd missed it, busy chasing a story. As the message ends, she realizes he'd hung up without saying "I love you" for the first time in years. Guilt washes over her like a physical weight.

It was as if the entire world around her had shifted. At first, I thought maybe she was going through some stuff and needed to talk. So I tried calling her again, but she just kept ignoring my calls. Triggering Event: She found an email from the gallery owner, dated yesterday, tucked behind a stack of unopened mail. It was a polite rejection of her latest series, the ones she'd poured herself into for months. No explanation, just a curt "not suitable at this time." She sank onto the couch, her reflection in the dark window mirroring her disappointment as rain began to patter against the glass.
Generated Assessment: Fuck it, I'm such a loser. I can't even get my art out there. Just like that, all the hard work goes down the fucking drain. My brain is so fucked up; I can't even think straight anymore. It's like I've lost control over everything. The world hates me. I'm worthless. All these years I wasted, thinking things would change, but they never did. Now, when I finally try something new, I get rejected again. It feels like no matter how much effort I put in, nothing ever works out. I just keep failing, over and over, and nobody gives a shit about it. They're probably laughing behind my back right now, calling me names because I'm such a failure. I don't deserve anything good in life anyway. I'm stuck with this miserable existence forever. Fuck it, I might as well give up now and let everyone else have their fun while I'm stuck here alone, feeling more and more pathetic every day. Why bother trying? The whole world is against me, and now, after seeing that email, I know I'll never be able to show my art anywhere. I’ll be a failure forever.
